Ian Badcoe wrote:

>Colin said that I said that he said that...
>  
>
>>[...]
>>Here you are collapsing the complete set of possible
>>board states into a more compact set that still represents the same
>>number of strategic states.
>>    
>>
>Exactly.
>  
>
>>Actually if this concept could be applied to
>>the 'Go' board state then we might have the basis of a real advance in
>>AI Go playing - something of a holy grail.
>>    
>>
>
>It can be applied to Go, but I think it helps a _lot_ less than you 
>imagine.  e.g. there are somewhere in the region of 2^350 Go board configs 
>and this reduces it by a bit under 8 fold....  Now if we could exploit the 
>translation and rotation of _parts_ of the Go board...
>  
>
I suppose you could use this technique (does it have a concise 
mathematical term?) to the input from a roving eye, thus removing the 
need for an ANN to drive the rotation of the eye itself. This does then 
mean that the eye is must analyse what it sees in isolation of what it 
just saw - e.g. normally it might detect patterns larger than the eye 
itself by sweeping over an area, but if we rotate the inputs then we 
break this kind of approach... unless we inform the eye of what rotation 
it is currently in. Has any of the people doing roving eye experiments 
used this approach of factoring out rotational invariance?

>
>OK, lets look at a 2x2 board.  There are four cells, which we can label 
>with letters:
>  
>
Ok yeh, thanks for explanation. This definitely sounds familair, perhaps 
you mentioned this in previous discussions. I definitely sounds like a 
superior approach to mine - that of playing opponents at all rotations - 
and I suspect it will definitely produce better players if I just switch 
my dominace chain experiment to this. The network's don't have to cover 
the same strategies from different rotations (which they see as 
different strategies) so the networks can perform better with less 
complexity, which in turn makes for faster evolution. And far fewer 
games are requried per evaluation, which speeds things up again. We are 
artificially helping NEAT along here a little, ideally NEAT would evolve 
a sub-network to do this work itself, but it still makes for an 
interesting experiment and the technique is potentially applicable to 
many other domains. It's certainly one to keep in teh ole tool belt :)

>It doesn't matter how you select the canonical board, any consistent 
>approach will do.  Obviously there may be some benefit to the networks if 
>the boards are chosen with some sort of systematic approach and for that 
>this way is quite good, because it is equivalent to attempting to place as 
>the filled squares first at the top, and then on the right.  You can even 
>tweak the encoding to give even more geometric choices, as long as no 
>ambiguities (boards with the same code) are introduced.
>  
>
I suppose it's possible to have all kinds of really complex encodings, 
some of which may include knowledge of particular board games and what 
patterns are important to that game. Or perhaps we could devise a 
parameterised encoding that could be controlled by an ANN - I'll leave 
that for someone with more IQ points than me to think about, I think 
I've reached my limit :)

>In practise, you might want to encode using 0 (empty), 1 (me), 2 (him) and 
>-1 might be better for the last case so that enemy pieces tend to get 
>sorted to the opposite corner.
>  
>
Yes, this is what I'm doing in my current experiments, I think I use 
-1,0,1 though. Same thing.

> >>In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
>
> >I bet I can get there before you... 2mins :)
>
>The milestone for delivery of the future has been put back again.
>  
>
hmm, I think you missed it. It's been and gone already.

Colin.
